data.title: Fickle Sentiment, High Yields: Why We Are Buying The BDC Panic
data.description:
Co-authored with Beyond Saving

Investor sentiment is fickle. There will be a news story that everyone is talking about as something so important to the markets. Then, a few months later, it just disappears.

Does anyone remember First Brands? We haven't seen anybody talk about it for months, but back in October 2025, First Brands was the excuse for the market to sell-off for credit risk investments. In particular, "private credit" was blamed, and investments like BDCs, private equity, and alternative asset managers sold off significantly. Nevermind that the debt was mostly owned and originated by banks, and private credit had little to do with it – that storyline has disappeared.

Now the market has focused on a new fear: AI and software. The current theory is that software companies aren't going to pay their loans because AI is going to disrupt their business.

Certainly, AI is going to "disrupt" many businesses in a similar manner that the Internet disrupted many businesses. That's technological innovation, and companies will adapt their business models.

No doubt some businesses might struggle with innovating and finding their path to provide value in a new world. That's life. Those who are lending first-lien senior secured loans to them, generally aren't the ones who end up feeling that risk.

When the market is fearful, it's time to go shopping for opportunities. Let's take a look at a few opportunities the market is giving us.

Pick #1: ARCC – Yield 10%

Ares Capital Corporation (ARCC) is one of our favorite buy-and-hold "forever" stocks. It is a premium BDC that focuses on the upper-middle market. It is an investment that frequently trades at a premium to NAV, but has recently started trading at a discount to its last reported NAV of $19.94.

What has changed? Well, nothing. ARCC is doing the same thing it has always done. Credit quality remains consistent with non-accruals at 1.8% of amortized cost and 1.2% of fair value: Source

ARCC's leverage remains low relative to their historical averages, and well within management's target range:

ARCC is doing the same thing that it has been doing for the past +20 years. One thing that has changed recently is investor sentiment. Investor sentiment is fickle.

ARCC does lend to software companies. They account for 24% of ARCC's portfolio.

This shouldn't be a surprise because software and services make up a very large portion of the U.S. economy, and lenders are going to lend to the businesses that make up most of the economy. ARCC's focus is on businesses that are in specialized niches with a fairly large moat.

For example, one of its top 10 largest investments is in Symplr, a company that specializes in providing enterprise-level software solutions to healthcare companies. For a healthcare system to change their software is a major and expensive step. The hard part isn't creating the software, it's in creating and maintaining the customer relationships. Even though it's one of the largest holdings in ARCC's portfolio, Symplr accounts for 1.2% of the portfolio.

ARCC lends to over 600 companies. They are highly diversified and there will always be some of their investments that are struggling. That was true in 2005, 2008, 2015, 2020, and today. The business model doesn't rely on every sector and every borrower being in great shape all the time. ARCC lends money, underwrites the collateral, and makes loans.

That's why, after over 20 years and $70 billion of closed investments, ARCC's annual realized net loss rate is insignificant. Source

So when ARCC is trading below book value, we are enthusiastic buyers.

Pick #2: OBDC – Yield 12.6%

Blue Owl Capital Corporation (OBDC) is a BDC that is managed by Blue Owl Capital Inc. (OWL). Over the past six months, we've seen the similarity in names cause quite a bit of volatility for OBDC. OWL has been garnering headlines for its investments in data centers and data center debt. Deals that have nothing to do with OBDC, but every negative headline about how "risky" these investments are seems to have an impact on OBDC's share price.

Then, OWL attempted to merge a non-traded BDC with OBDC. The market threw a tantrum, and the deal was called off as the decline in OBDC's share price made it unpalatable. Many questioned the value of the assets.

Well, OWL just proved the value, selling $1.4 billion across three of its funds: OBDC, OTIC, and OBDC II, the non-traded fund. The loans are being sold at 99.8% of par value to pensions and insurance companies. The batch of loans includes a 13% allocation to "software and services" – the favorite sector for bears to be bashing these days. (OBDC's allocation to the sector was 11%)

In short, OWL just proved that their portfolio is worth well more than the market is currently pricing in.

OBDC reported earnings with adjusted NII of $0.36 and book value at $14.81, generally in line with Q3: Source

Note that this does not reflect the sale of assets discussed above. That sale occurred on February 12th, 2026 and will be reflected in Q1 earnings. That's likely why OBDC is paying a dividend of $0.37 for another quarter, even though that is slightly more than earnings were in Q4.

Management took advantage of the discount to NAV that OBDC has been trading at by buying back $148 million in stock in November/December 2025. They also announced a buyback program to buy up to another $300 million in 2026. These buybacks were at a price averaging 86% of NAV.

This slightly offset the credit-related markdowns of $0.14 in Q4.

The overall credit picture of the portfolio remains stable. Non-accruals came in at 2.3% of cost basis and 1.1% of fair value – slightly better than Q3 at 2.7% and 1.3%, respectively.

Over 90% of OBDC's portfolio remains in their top two credit ratings.

While the public markets have been bearish on OBDC, the private markets haven't been. OBDC had its credit rating bumped up a notch by Moody's in January to Baa2. While their debt was already investment grade, being a notch higher will be a small benefit when they go to refinance their debt. BDCs borrow at fixed rates and lend at floating rates. Being able to refinance the fixed-rate debt at the lowest possible coupon is a long-term benefit for the company that improves earnings.

When we bought OBDC over 5 years ago, we said we believed that OBDC deserved to trade at a premium to NAV. Then it did trade at a premium for a bit. Today, OBDC is a stronger company by every measure. It has better economies of scale, it has higher earnings, it has a higher credit rating, and it has maintained a similarly low credit loss rate. We believe that OBDC should be trading at 100-110% of NAV, which is $14.81-$16.29. That is fair value, and management just proved it in the most straightforward way possible, by selling assets to prove their worth. Our neighbors in the market are giving us an opportunity to buy it at a big discount.

Conclusion

When the market panics, look for the opportunity it is giving you. BDCs have been off to a rough start in 2026. In part, this is due to the reality that their earnings are normalizing. The rapid increase in interest rates created a windfall that we all knew wasn't going to last forever. BDCs borrow at fixed-rates and lend at floating rates, so higher interest rates produced higher than average spreads for them. That is over. We expect that earnings will continue to drift down and return to their historical averages.

They are still paying a high yield, even without the supplements, and there are opportunities to monetize their portfolio either through selling a portion of their positions like OBDC did, or as portfolio companies have IPOs, are acquired, or have other liquidity events. In periods of low interest rates, we tend to see more of that type of activity.

For those of us looking to buy and hold long-term, these BDCs are trading below book value, and they should be trading at book value or at a premium. We're buying.

data.title: Nebius: Sell Before The AI Bubble Bursts
data.description:
As one of the most popular neocloud providers, Nebius (NBIS) was able to greatly benefit from the record capital spending by the hyperscalers on the AI infrastructure last year, which made it possible for the company to quickly scale its business. In the last year, Nebius’s shares have already appreciated at a triple-digit rate and gained additional momentum in the last year and a half after Microsoft (MSFT) announced a deal to rent the company’s GPU infrastructure capacity to execute its AI projects.

However, Nebius also faces significant challenges that could limit its upside in the future. The company has a capital-intensive business model that requires it to spend the available resources to build new data centers to meet the growing demand for its services. More importantly, since the business is unprofitable while the FCF is negative, Nebius needs to constantly access the capital markets to raise additional funds, which has already increased its debt load. If the hyperscalers decide to scale down their AI expenses or the macro environment worsens, there’s a risk that Nebius’s growth rate will decelerate. As such, we can’t recommend buying or holding the company’s shares right now and rate Nebius as a sell.

The Challenges That Nebius Faces Are Significant

Nebius specializes in building large-scale GPU clusters, which it later rents to other companies that are interested in using them to execute their AI projects. With the rise of generative AI, the demand for such services has skyrocketed, and it’s not a surprise that in Q4, Nebius’s revenues increased by an impressive 546.9% Y/Y to $227.7 million.

In the future, Nebius could now expect to generate over $3 billion in revenues annually in the next five years from the Microsoft deal alone. There are also reports that under the deal, Microsoft would get access to over 100,000 GB300 chips that are owned by Nebius and will use them for its AI workloads. A similar deal that’s worth around $3 billion was signed with Meta Platforms (META) a few months ago. While this ensures that Nebius will be able to significantly improve its top-line performance in years to come, there are nevertheless major risks with its business model that make investing in the company an extremely risky endeavor.

First of all, by signing such deals, Nebius will take most of the risks associated with expanding the AI infrastructure. The deal gives Microsoft and Meta financial flexibility as they could pay for access to the computing power when there’s an increase in demand for its AI projects, and also not pay an enormous cost for building and maintaining a data center when the demand has fallen.

At the same time, Nebius risks being left holding outdated GPUs that are quickly depreciating as more powerful chips are introduced. In 2024, following the success of its GPUs from the Hopper series, Nvidia said that it plans to release new AI accelerators each year. Last year, we already saw the ramp-up in production of its GPUs from the Blackwell series, and the company expects to release accelerators from the Rubin series later in 2026. This could suggest that as more powerful chips are introduced, Nebius would be required to constantly spend resources on new GPUs to expand its data center footprint and remain competitive.

We already see this happening since Nebius’s CapEx is expected to be in the range of $16 billion to $20 billion, an increase from $4.07 billion in 2025. The problem is that the company’s business is unprofitable and is expected to lose money in the following years. As such, Nebius is expected to access the capital markets for a while to expand its AI infrastructure. In June, it already raised $1 billion through the issuance of convertible notes. Then, in September, it began to raise an additional $3.75 billion through the issuance of new notes and shares. The problem with this is that it increases the company’s debt load and will likely dilute its existing shareholders. In recent quarters, Nebius’s total debt has already greatly increased. Considering that Nebius is likely to remain unprofitable, while its CapEx increases and the FCF remains negative, the company will likely continue to access the capital markets to scale its business.

This is a big red flag for us, since there’s no guarantee that after all this spending, Nebius will be able to reach profitability and become FCF positive in the foreseeable future to avoid issuing new debt and shares. Some reports from last year indicate that even Oracle (ORCL) struggles with improving the margins of its business that rents Nvidia’s chips and even loses money on rentals in some cases. In addition, with AI bubble fears on the rise, there’s a risk that if the demand for large-scale GPU clusters decreases, then Nebius could be left with lots of depreciating GPUs and a limited ability to turn things around and become profitable. That’s why we find it hard to justify a long position in Nebius, especially considering that the challenges that the company faces are on the rise, while its stock already trades at exuberant multiples.

The Real Value of Nebius

Considering all the issues described above, we decided to create a valuation model and figure out the real value of Nebius in the current environment. In the model, our forecast period includes the next five years, and the perpetual growth rate that we use is 3%, which is close to the historical inflation and GDP growth rate. The cash and debt numbers have been taken from the recent earnings report.

The discount rate that we use is 10.12%. We figured it out by calculating the cost of debt and the cost of equity of Nebius. When calculating the cost of equity, we used the TTM numbers for the interest expense and the total debt numbers from the latest earnings report. For the cost of equity, we used a risk-free rate of 4%, a beta of 2.05, and the market return rate of 7.84%.

When it comes to sales estimates, we expect the company to continue to grow significantly in the years to come. The deal with Microsoft under the maximum extension alone would be able to generate around $3.8 billion annually, while the deal with Meta should yield around $600 million annually in the next five years. The management even stated in the latest earnings call that they’re on track to reach around $7 billion to $9 billion in annualized run-rate revenue, so the aggressive growth rate is expected. We reflected this in the model, and we also assume a continuous double-digit growth rate in all the other years, since in the same call, the management stated that the projects that they plan to implement this year could lay the foundation for the hyper growth in 2027 and beyond.

As for the bottom-line performance, things don’t look as good. The expectations right now are that Nebius will remain unprofitable in the upcoming years. Morgan Stanley expects the AI spending to deliver returns only by 2028. Considering this, we assume in the model that Nebius’s EBIT will become positive only in 2028, while in 2026, it’s going to be only slightly better in comparison to its TTM margin. The tax rate in our model is 15%, which is the rate we mostly use when valuing other companies from the AI field.

As for the depreciation & amortization, it has been relatively high in the past, and we assume that that remains to be the case in the future. This is because the AI accelerators that Nebius purchases depreciate fairly quickly due to the constant release of more powerful chips, which leads to a drop in the value of older chips.

When it comes to the capital expenditures, during the latest conference call, the management said that they expect the spending this year to be in the range of $16 billion to $20 billion. We reflected this in the model. At the same time, we also expect a major increase in spending in the following years. Let’s not forget that Nebius’s management in the same call also said that they expect to achieve 800 megawatts to 1 gigawatts of connected power by around year-end, and achieve over 3 gigawatts of contracted power by the end of 2026. Since it was also noted that the acceleration of the data center build-out will continue in 2027 and beyond, we could expect a major expansion of computing capacity that would require lots of capital spending in the future. That’s why we believe that the major increase in CapEx assumptions in the next few years is more than justified.

When it comes to the assumptions for the change in net working capital, they are not that far from the company’s historical performance.

Under all of those assumptions, our model shows that the enterprise value of Nebius is $18.69 billion, while its equity value is $17.48 billion. That translates to an intrinsic value of $69.08 per share, below the current market price by 30.09% at the time of this writing.

Risks To Our Bearish Thesis

Nebius’s stock could nevertheless appreciate further along with the rest of the market if the macro environment improves. The latest CPI numbers suggest that inflation is not reaccelerating, which makes it possible for the Federal Reserve to continue to cut interest rates in the following quarters as macro risks subside.

In addition, the improving macro environment could prompt hyperscalers to continue to increase their spending on AI infrastructure to another record level, which would be beneficial to neocloud providers like Nebius.

Final Thoughts

While it’s possible that Nebius will continue to trade at the excessive multiples and its share price appreciates further, especially if another major deal is announced, we find it hard to justify a long position right now. Due to the excessive capital spending, the company is unlikely to generate any positive FCF in the next few years, and it will likely be required to once again raise additional capital that will increase its debt load even more. At the same time, at the current market price, Nebius doesn’t offer any decent margin of safety, while the risks that the business faces are significant. That is why we decided to rate Nebius as a sell.

data.title: Iran Escalation: Oil Shock, Gold Surge, Equity Risk
data.description:
I don't know about you, but I feel like I woke up this Saturday morning to a world that has been forever altered, and there is no doubt our investment portfolio will look a lot different come Monday. Over the last two hours, it's safe to say that all of those diplomatic efforts over many years of "strategic patience" have gone up in flames. At the time of my writing this article for Seeking Alpha, on Saturday, the Israeli Air Force ('IAF'), while being supported both logistically and operationally by the U.S., attacked previously unknown strategic and nuclear targets in the center of Iran.

A very important note before we begin: on Seeking Alpha, I will ignore the politics, ethics, and emotions involved with war. This is NOT because I do not feel they are important (they are VERY IMPORTANT). It is simply that this is an economics/finance space, and my purpose here is to make connections to assist you in understanding what occurred and how it will affect the markets when Monday morning's opening bell rings.

Buckle in; we’re going to cover some rough seas together.

From Switzerland to the Bombs

With no small amount of speed, we have moved from where Omani mediators said the parties were "close" to the complete collapse of diplomacy announced by President Trump. This is the worst possible outcome for the markets because, as you all are aware, the markets do not like uncertainty. If the diplomatic process collapses, that leaves nothing but volatility.

Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the markets will be factoring in this next phase when they open on Monday. Thus, the spotlight will most naturally be focused upon the reliability of the global energy infrastructure, which represents a far greater risk than mere sanctions. I will elaborate upon this within the full article.

Compared to what has been done so far, I must admit that today's attack is different and cannot be compared to past skirmishes. Why? Indeed, if you think about it, the Israeli attack on Tehran, particularly given its proximity to sensitive areas of power (Khamenei's office and residence), represents a change because a "red line" that had existed for a long time has been crossed. Up until this point, it was just testing and probing the territory; now we are entering a more serious phase.

When the explicit reference to wanting to "eliminate the nuclear threat once and for all" is made, the message becomes clear enough to identify who the target might be. It would be possible to hit, for example, highly protected underground installations such as Fordow or Natanz. These kinds of operations are necessarily long-term in scope (because they can't be finished off in a few days) and will inevitably enter into a longer-term cycle of responses and counter-responses.

And then there is another very sensitive issue: Trump invited the Iranians to "take back their government" in the last part of his almost eight minutes of speaking about it. At this point, the operation plan goes from being simply military to a clearly political one, which has all the internal instability implications on the country.

Oil and the OPEC+ Trap

As I said before, my first thought goes to the potential victims of this conflict, but my second focus, as an asset manager and analyst, is clearly on the markets and the economic implications. This is also because we're on a platform that discusses financial markets, and it's appropriate to focus on this topic.

So, coming to the crux of the matter: what will happen on Monday in the markets?

The following is my very personal view. I don't trust weekend OTC contracts, which are always very erratic, even if they represent a potential market reaction. That said, my thoughts are as follows.

Many have been suggesting that we shouldn’t be concerned with oil, as OPEC+ has agreed to produce more oil. I feel that this is an overly simplistic way of thinking about the problem. It's not just a matter of how much oil Iran can produce; it's also a matter of how much oil (CO1:COM) Iran can deliver to the marketplace. Iran is not an insignificant player in terms of supplying oil to the world. Iran is the 4th largest oil-producing country within OPEC and supplies approximately 11-12% of all OPEC oil production, which equates to about 3.3 million bbl/day of oil supply. Any disruption to the flow of oil from Iran (whether due to more stringent sanctions or damage to its infrastructure) would immediately shrink the size of the global oil market.

The major issue, however, is a logistics issue. Oil is a physical product that has to be moved, and as you know, a significant amount of the oil passing from the Gulf passes through the Strait of Hormuz, which is actually the world’s only energy funnel.

Approximately 16 million barrels of oil are transported through this strait on a daily basis, and at the narrowest part of the strait, the width is approximately 30 km with very few shipping lanes available in that area. This therefore means that if no complete blockage occurs, it will only take creating additional risk factors (mines, drones, GPS interference, etc.) or increasing the level of military tension in the area to slow the flow of ships and quickly increase both shipping and insurance costs.

I think OPEC+, on its own, can’t solve the issue of price increases because if Saudi Arabia were to pump more oil, there are already alternative pipelines out of the Gulf, but they’re nowhere near as large as those through the Strait of Hormuz. The Strait is so narrow that, while it’s possible to create some alternatives, it will be difficult to get enough oil out of the Gulf to replace the volume going through the Strait each day. As such, if the Strait becomes an operational constraint, the market may face a sudden supply deficit (a deficiency) that no amount of rapid production increases from OPEC+ can quickly make up for; thus, the risk to the price of oil is much greater now than would initially appear.

Gold, Equities, and the King Dollar

The word of the day on Monday will probably be risk-off because during times of conflict or instability, the markets are always seeking shelter from the storm, so to speak.

Dollar

I start by looking at the Dollar (DXY). Although the U.S.A. is actively involved in this scenario, based upon historical precedent, the USD continues to be viewed as the safe-haven currency when the markets are stressed. It is the currency of choice for paying for oil and raw materials and for most other global transactions. Therefore, in the short term, I think we should anticipate a stronger dollar.

Gold

Gold (XAUUSD) should act like it usually does during a period of chaos and provide investors with some protection from the uncertainties that are currently affecting the market. The fact that gold hit an all-time price before the most recent tensions indicates that the markets have already begun to account for this type of tension. If the instability continues, I think you may see additional increases in the price of gold. However, due to the large degree of volatility that is associated with the type of rapid increase in the price of gold, I think it would be prudent to use caution.

Equities

The most key component is the sensitivity of stocks over the short term, i.e., an extremely negative opening price resulting from uncertainty could cause investors to flee to safe havens. However, the true test of a market will ultimately take place not on the first day of trading but on whether subsequent closing prices remain relatively stable. If the S&P 500 index (SPX) continues to fall below levels of support, this could provide a perfect narrative for an orderly reversal of markets following prolonged periods of high valuation.

The most notable difference in today’s environment is that there are three new, highly sensitive factors influencing the markets:

  1. logistical risks associated with Hormuz,
  2. the threat of inflationary pressures brought about by increasing oil prices,
  3. China's position as one of the largest consumers of Iranian crude oil.

It doesn’t necessarily mean a bear market has begun, but it does help to explain how the reaction could be more fearful in nature. In this context, maintaining a significant amount of liquidity remains a rational choice. For me, now is not the time to chase the panic of the opening but to maintain vigilant patience and be ready if volatility were to create real price dislocations. From a financial perspective, cynicism is simply having the discipline to remain focused while all the other players around you are reacting emotionally, allowing you to make decisions based upon your own time frame (i.e., when you want to act).

It's Only Saturday
